titlePage.docImprint: Vol. Xxv — no.64 Richmond, Va. Monday, September 14, 1863 Price one Cent

div1.head:
Richmond Dispatch
by Cowardin & Hammersley.
div1.p:
the Daily Dispatch is served to subscribers at six and A Quarter Cents per week, payable to the Carrier weekly.
Price for mailing, $4 a year, or $2.50 for six months, in advance.
the Semi-Weekly Dispatch is issued every Tuesday and Friday at $2.00, in advance.
the Weekly Dispatch is issued every Friday, and mailed to subscribers at $1 per annum.
Advertisements published until forbid, will be charged 50 cents per square of eight lines for the first insertion, and 25 cents for each continuance

div3.head: A desirable
div3.p:
little Farm or Market Garden, five miles from the city, on the Deep Run turnpike, for sale privately.--It contains 12¼ acres, 8½ of which are cleared, and the balance in woods.
The hours is new, and has four rooms.
There are, besides, barn, stables, &c, all in complete order.
Also, a large number of excellent fruit trees.
The land has been recently heavily manured, and is in the highest state of improvement, as the extensive and flourishing crop of vegetables of all kinds now growing will show.
As immediate possession will be given the purchaser will at once receive large returns from the vegetables now ready for market.
There will also be about 50 barrels of corn.
The implements, wagon, cart, &c, will also be sold to the purchaser of the farm.
Apply to.

div3.head: We
div3.p:
are authorized to sell privately a tract of land in Hanover county, lying four miles west of Ashland containing 109¼ acres; one-third in original growth, balance in second growth of pine, fifty acres of which is large enough to cut into cord wood.
It lies on a public road and adjoins the lands of Richard Thomas, Eldridge Cross, Charles R Montgomery, and others.
For terms, &c, apply to

div3.head: For sale
div3.p:
--A very valuable and productive farm of 27 acres, 3½ miles from the city; 600 cords of wood, of which 150 are now corded and seasoned, can be sold from the place.
Also, crops, stock, farming supplements, &c. This farm offers unusual inducements to purchasers.
Apply at No. 20 Pearl st.

lots of land, on new Central Road, about 1½ miles below Richmond, for sale. --We are authorized to sell two lots of land located as above, one containg 11 782 1000 acres, and the other 10 135 1000 acres.

div3.head: Valuable
div3.p:
Farm in the upper part of Dinwiddie county, near the Brunswick line and Cut Bank Bridge, over the Nottoway river, 27 miles from Petersburg, 18 or 20 miles from the South Side railroad, and 11 miles from Dinwiddie court house, for sale privately.--At the request of Col. John Goode I offer for sale privately the above valuable tract of Land, containing about 700 acres, 300 acres of which are well timbered, being mostly of original growth.
The soil is fair and well adapted to the growth of wheat and tobacco.
The land is well watered, a small creek passing through it, on the margin of which there is a small portion of low grounds.
The improvements consist of a comfortable dwelling with 4 rooms and the usual out buildings, in tolerable good order.
Possession of the land will be given in time for the fall crops, and full possession on the 1st Jan, 1864.

in the town of Boydton, Mecklenburg county, for sale privately.--At the request of Capt. C R Edmondson I offer for sale, privately, two Houses and Lots in the above named town.
The first is a large framed dwelling, with seven rooms, together with about eleven cabins in the yard, that can accommodate a number of persons, with servants quarters attached.
The lot contains about one acre.

The second is a comfortable dwelling, with six rooms, including two basement rooms, with a large hall or passage.
There is a small building in the yard suitable for an office, together with the usual out houses, all in good order.
The lot contains about three fourths of an acre, with an excellent garden.
Terms to suit the purchaser.

div3.head: We
div3.p:
are authorized by Mr. W. P. Pierce to sell, privately, a tract of Land in Powhatan county, about seven miles from Powhatan Station, on the Richmond and Danville Railroad, near the Buckingham or Flat Rock Road, about five miles from Powhatan C H, about four miles from James river, adjoining the lands of Messrs. Pleasants, Forlorn, and McGruder.
It contains about 160 acres, half cleared, balance in oak and pine.
The dwelling house has four rooms and passage, kitchen, stable, &c, all of logs.
The buildings not in very good order.
A fine spring of water near the house and a creek passing through the farm.
Price, $5,000 cash.
Possession will be given immediately.
Apply to

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p:
--I will sell my Farm, consisting of between five and six hundred acres of land in Buckingham county, two miles from the Canal, at Fallsburg, and three miles from Warran, a depot on the canal.
From 250 to 300 under fence; the balance well timbered.
There is a frame dwelling-house, with five rooms in it, and all necessary out-buildings, with yard and garden newly pailed in. The farm is well watered, with good lasting springs in each field; also, a creek running through the farm, with a good hill seat.
Terms of sale made accommodating.
Possession for seeding this fall given immediately, and fall possession the 15th November next.
Address
div3.closer:
J M Tapott,
Warran P O. Va. se 11--3t*

div3.head: Farm
div3.p:
is 203½ Acres, in Hanover County, 7 Miles West of Ashland, For Sale.--We are authorized to sell, privately, the above tract of Land, containing 203½ acres, on which there is a good dwelling-house of four rooms, three on the lower floor, and one above, with a good basement, not finished; also, kitchen, barn, stable, and other out-houses; an excellent orchard of select fruit.
There is a fine spring of water near the dwelling.
The location is healthy, and the neighborhood good.
About one-half of the land is cleared, the balance in timber.
This land is seven miles west of Ashland, adjoining the lands of Wm O Day, James Winston, and others, and within one and a half miles of two excellent mills.

We will also sell a Lot of about three acres, adjoining the foregoing, upon which there is a large carpenter shop and a blacksmith's shop.
This is a fine location for a country store.
For terms, &c, apply to

div3.head: For sale
div3.p:
--A place on the Manchester turnpike, just above the toll-gate, containing 4 acres of land, 5 rooms to the house, smoke-house, stable, a good well of water in 20 feet of the house, and also a good crop of corn, cabbage, sweet and irish potatoes on it. Any person wishing to purchase call immediately.
Possession given as soon as sold.
Also, another small place on the same road, containing about a half acre of land, four rooms to the house, and garden set in cabbage and potatoes.
div3.closer:
Archer Dyer,
On the premises. se 11--3t*

div3.head: For sale
div3.p:
--A beautiful Farm, very near Fredericksburg, containing about 600 acres, 400 of which are arable and very fertile, the balance growing up in wood.
The improvements are a substantial brick dwelling, nearly new, containing sixteen rooms, an excellent grist mill, and other houses.--Apply to R R Howison, Richmond, or to the proprietor, on the premises.

div3.head: Desirable
div3.p:
Farm of 157 acres in Hanover county, near to Salem Church, 16 miles east of Richmond, for sale.--We are authorized to sell the desirable Farm on which Mr. Charles P Cross now resides, containing 157 acres, and adjoining the lands of Dr. George W Pollard, John Haw, and G W Ellett.
The improvements consist of a dwelling with five rooms, carriage house, corn house, stable, &c. Possession given at once.
Price $35 per acre.
The crops, &c, can be bought at valuation.
The neighborhood is an excellent one.
Apply to

div3.head: For sale
div3.p:
--Privately, my Farm in Chesterfield county, containing 434 acres, lying three miles south of Coalfield Station, on the Richmond and Danville railroad.
It has on it a comfortable dwelling with six rooms, the necessary out houses, and an abundance of wood and timber.
For a further description of the land refer to Messrs Peter G Cosby & Co, commission merchants, Richmond, or to the subscriber, living on the premises.

div3.head: Chancellorsville Farm,
div3.p:
in Spotsylvania county, containing 854 acres, for sale.--We are authorized to sell the above Farm, situated on the plank-road leading from Fredericksburg to Orange Court House, 10 miles distant from Fredericksburg, containing 854 acres, (two acres reserved for family grave yard) The land is good and lies well for cultivation, is well wooded, and has about 250 acres of cleared land, mostly fine upland meadow.
There is an overseer's house on the place — the dwelling and other buildings were destroyed by the enemy.
The walls of the large brick dwelling supposed to contain 300,000 bricks, are still standing.
For terms apply to

div3.head: Land for sale.
div3.p:
--The subscribers will offer at public auction, at Rice's Depot, on the South-Side railroad, in the county of Prince Edward, Va, on Friday, the 18th of September next, two tracts of land.
One contains 555 acres of land and lies four miles from the depot; the other contains 600; and lies one mile from the depot.
Both tracts are well wooded, watered, and convenient, and stand high as excellent farms.
The surplus timber alone on these farms is worth a large sum. Persons seeking an investment will do well to examine for themselves.
Terms--Cash, in Confederate money.
Address, South Boston, Halifax, Va.

div3.head: Beautiful building Lot,
div3.p: on the South side of Clay, between Adams street and Brook avenue, for sale.--We are authorized to sell that most valuable Lot located as above, adjoining the residence of Mr. Dabney M Miller, fronting 30 feet, running back 150 feet to an alley.

div3.head: Land for sale.
div3.p:
--About 1,300 acres in Nicholas county, Va, 200 of which is cleared; the balance heavily timbered; good veins of coal also on the tract.
Title unquestionable.
Apply to

div3.head: Harness Manufactory.
div3.p:
--Having sold out my saddle and harness establishment to Messrs Taylor & Smith, I cordially recommend them to my former patrons.
They will keep always on hand and make to order all kinds of harness and saddles.
div3.closer:
David A Brown,
Opposite New Theatre. se 8--5t*

div3.head: Book and news Ink.
div3.p:
--Book and News Ink for sale, a good quality, in kegs and barrels.
Call on
div3.closer:
Darby, Read & Gentry,
Selvia's Block, 12th st, se --1w

div3.head: For sale
div3.p:
--A comfortable family residence, near Chimborazo Hospital, containing 7 rooms, together with one acre of corn and Irish potatoes, cabbage, &c., sufficient for one year's consumption for a large family.
There is one ton of good coal and a half cord of oak wood in the wood house, a well of the purest water, and, altogether, a desirable, quiet place to live in. Particulars can be obtained by applying to the undersigned.
div3.closer:
King & son, Scourers,
Near the Spotswood. se 14--6t*

div3.head: For Rent.
div3.p: --The large and beautifully situated Lot at corner of 19th and Cary streets, with the building thereon, two stories high, 40x40, lately used as the Quaker Meeting-House — all well enclosed.
Also for hire, by the day or week, an able bodied Negro Man. Apply to, or address,

div3.head: For Rent
div3.p:
--A House, on Union Hill, corner 23d and M streets, containing four rooms, kitchen, Wood-house, etc, and good-sized garden connected to the premises, Possession had the 1st October.
For terms, &c, apply to
div3.closer:
Clopton & Lyne,
Corner Wall and Franklin sts. se 14--ts

div3.head: The valuable st. Charles Hotel for sale.
div3.p:
--At the request of the owners, we offer for sale this very valuable Hotel.
It is so well known that it is deemed unnecessary to speak of its peculiar advantages, as they are well known to all. For further particulars, apply to

div3.head: Horse for sale.
div3.p: --A very fine large grey Stallion, gentle and sound, with English Saddle, Bridle, &c. Apply corner Cary and 19th streets.

div3.head: For Rent
div3.p:
--Two floors, containing several large and desirable Rooms, suitable for families, with gas, closets, &c, pleasantly situated, on Mayo st, six or eight doors from Broad, convenient to any part of the city.
To good occupants they will be rented on reasonable terms.
Apply after 3 o'clock P. M.

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p: --Any person desirous of purchasing a beautiful Residence, containing ten rooms, in the most desirable part of the city can do so by addressing "Box 362," Richmond.

div3.head: For Rent
div3.p: --A Store House, on 15th street.

div3.head: Valuable
div3.p:
Farm of 600 acres in Henrico, on the Chickahominy, 14 miles below Richmond, and one mile from the York river railroad, for rent.--At the request of the executrix, we offer for rent the truly valuable farm located as above, on which the late Dr. John G Carter resided at the time of his death, and now occupied by Mr. George P K. There is a fine dwelling and all out houses for a large family.
About 400 acres open land, in fine heart, and much valuable meadow land.
Price $1,000. Possession given 1st January next.
Apply to

div3.head: For private sale
div3.p:
--A two-story framed house, situated in the most business place in the city.
Apply on 17th st, between Main and Franklin, opposite the market, at Mrs. Murphy's.

div3.head: For Rent
div3.p:
--The spacious iron-front Warehouse on Governor street recently occupied by us. Possession given immediately.
For terms apply to
div3.closer:
Sumner & Arents, Auct'rs,
Corner Main and 13th sts. se 4--2w

div3.head: Two hundred and fifty Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Ranaway from the subscriber on Wednesday, the 9th inst, one negro man named Henry, aged about 30 years, medium height, dark copper color, weighs about 165 pounds, and came from Chester District, S. C. He may attempt to get back to that State.
He was supposed to have been caught on the same day, but broke and ran from his captor.
I will give two hundred and fifty dollars reward for his apprehension and delivery to Messrs Hill, Dickinson & Co, or confined in any jail so I get him.

div3.head: Ranaway
div3.p:
from my service, on the night of the 10th inst, negro girl Sally. She is about 18 or 20 years of age; color nearly black; of medium stature and genteel appearance.
I will give $25 for her apprehension, it taken in or about the city, or $50 if taken more than ten miles out.
div3.closer:
O Fairfax,
Grace st, bet 3d and 4th. se 14--3t*

div3.head: Fifty Dollars reward
div3.p:
--Will be paid for the apprehension of Ann and her child Eliza, who left my farm, near Powhatan depot, on the 20th ult. Ann is a good looking black woman, about 40 years old, of medium size, and responds quickly and intelligently when spoken to. The girl is about seven years old, very intelligent, and a little limber jawed.
They were purchased of Mr. D R Williams, of Lynchburg, on the 15th of August, and are supposed to be making their way, by Petersburg, to Warrenton, N C, having been sold in Richmond by Mr. Quincy, agent for Mrs. B J Hays; of Warren county, last May, I will pay the above reward of fifty dollars it placed in jail so that I can get them.

div3.head:
Richmond and Danville Railroad,
Superintendent's office,
Richmond, Sept. 10, 1863.
div3.p:
Ran Away from near Powhatan Station, Richmond and Danville Railroad, Abner, a slave boy hired of Dr. Dorsett.
He is about 6 feet high, ginger-bread color, and when spoken to speaks very slow, and is quite an intelligent looking boy. The usual reward will be paid for his apprehension.
div3.closer:
Chas G Talcott,
Sup't R -- D R R. se 12--5t

div3.head: Ran Away
div3.p:
from Camp Winder Hospital, on the 31st day of August, 1863, my servant man Paul.
He is about 21 years of age, black, smooth skin, about 5 feet 7 or 8 inches high, thick set, quick spoken, limps slightly, owing to an affection of one of the little toes, commonly known as "cow itch." He was formerly from Jefferson county, where he may aim to go, or to Charlottesville, where he was hired last year.
I will give $100 reward if delivered to me at said Hospital, or secured in some jail, so that I get him again.
div3.closer:
E Lee Wager, M D,
1st Div'n, Camp Winder Hosp'l. se 11--3t*

div3.head: Richmond, September 12, 1863.
div3.p: Exchange notice, No. 6.--The following Confederate officers and men, captured at Vicksburg, Miss., July 4th, 1863, and subsequently paroled, have been duly exchanged, and are hereby so declared:

list.item:
1.
The officers and men of Gen C L Stevenson's division.
2. The officers and men of Gen. Bowen's division.

3. The officers and men of Brig Gen.
Moore's brigade.
4. The officers and men of 2d Texas regiment.

5.
The officers and men of Waul's legion.
6. Also, all Confederate officers and men who have been delivered at City Point at any time previous to July 25th, 1863, have been duly exchanged, and are hereby so declared.

div3.closer:
Ro Ould,
Agent of Exchange.
Southern papers copy six times and send bills to the War Department. se 14--6t

div3.head:
Chimborazo Hospital,
Sept. 12th, 1863.
div3.p:
All patients in private quarters from this Hospital will report in person to their respective divisions on or before Thursday, Sept. 17th.
If they do not appear at that time they will be inspected at their own houses on the succeeding day.

div3.head:
[Extract.]
Adjutant & Inspector Gen's office,
Richmond, Sept. 11th 1863.
special orders, no. 216.--
div3.p:
XXVI.
Major J W Malleit, P A C S Artillery, heretofore assigned to duty in the Ordnance Department, is hereby officially announced as Superintendent C S Laboratories of the Ordnance Department, with headquarters at Macon, Ga.
div3.closer:
By command of the Secretary of War.
Jno Withers.
Assistant Adjutant General. se 12--1w

div3.head:
Headq'rs German mounted guard,
Richmond, Sept. 11, 1863.
div3.p:
Meet at Old Fairfield Monday, Sept. 11, at 4½ P. M, for drill.
Sergeants will report at 4¼ P. M.
div3.closer:
By order. C A Schwagerle, Com'g.
C T Ganter, O S. se 12--2t*

div3.head: Henrico mounted guard.
div3.p: --Meet for drill at the County Court-House, on Wednesday, 16th instant, at 3 o'clock P. M.
div3.closer:
By order of Capt. S McRae.
Jno H MacKENZIEenzie, O. S. se 12--4t*

div3.head:
Headq'rs Mayo's mounted guard,
Richmond, Sept. 10, 1863.
div3.p:
Meet in front of the City Hall, Saturday, Sept. 12, at 4½ P. M, for drill.
Sergeants will report at 4¼ P. M.
div3.closer:
By order Lt. Baker, Com'g.
Gervas Strorrs, O S. se 11--2t

div3.head: Attention.
div3.p:
--15 more men wanted to complete the organization of a company of cavalry in Maj. Gilmor's independent battalion.
Horses, equipments, and bounty furnished.
Apply immediately at the office of J G Hedgeman, on Bank, between 10th and 11th streets.

Dollars Bounty to all youths between the ages of 15 and 18 who enlist in Capt H D Burr's company, to muster in Major Munford's battalion, for special and local defence of the city of Richmond.
Apply at camp, near the old Fair Grounds.

div3.head: If Mrs. S S Rind,
div3.p: widow of the late Samuel S Rind, Esq. of Richmond, Va, is in the city, she will hear from her relatives by applying to.

div3.head: Wm T Burwell,
div3.p: of Jenkins's cavalry, Stuart's division, will learn something to his advantage by addressing "Box 1,515," Richmond Post-Office, and giving number of regiment and company, and where stationed.

div3.head: Wood.
div3.p: --50 cords Pine and Oak Wood, dry and well seasoned, for sale by
div3.closer:
Whitlock & Roane,
Cor 15th and Dock sts. se 12--2t*

div3.head: Wants
div3.p:
--A situation, by a first-class Manager, with the experience of twenty years; the most of that time having the entire control of business under his charge; ten years of that time with Col. G A Washington, at Mount Vernon., The best of reference given.
Any one wishing to employ such an one will address me at Carter's Bridge, Albemarle county, or I can be seen at P S Coles's, on the Green Mountain, eight miles from Scottsville, or address my son, W H H Turner, at the Tredegar Iron Works.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--A lady of experience, thoroughly qualified to instruct in the usual English branches, and in vocal and instrumental music on the piano and guitar, desires a situation, either in a public school or private family.
The best reference given and required.
Address, stating terms, &c, "Box 49," Staunton, Va.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--A gentleman of extensive experience desires to get a situation on a large farm as Overseer.
The best of recommendations can be given.
Persons in want will address me at Richmond, or call on me, on the Westham Plankroad, 4 miles above Richmond.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--A single man, (a discharged soldier preferred,) to take charge of a small farm within four miles of Richmond.
He must understand the cultivation of truck patches.
Liberal wages paid.
Address "L," Dispatch office.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--A Lady, middle-aged, without children, to keep house for a small family.
For particulars and an interview, address "Box 439" P O, Richmond.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p: --A good Cook, Washer and Ironer, without encumbrance, for a small family.
div3.closer:
A Judson Crane,
11th st, bet Main and Bank. se 14--2t*

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--Would like to buy 2 large size Screws and 2 small ones.
Any person having them for sale will leave their names at this office, addressed to "C."

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--A Teacher for a small private school of four or five scholars, who is capable of teaching English, Latin and, French, and a good Mathematician.
References given and required.
Address "Box 894," stating terms.
Board can be obtained with the family.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p: --Those who have Universalist Books which they wish to dispose of, will address "C M," box 516, giving the names of books and where they can be seen.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--Two or three good hands to cut wood, about four miles from Richmond, in Chesterfield county.
Address "B," Box 331, Richmond, Va.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--Music Scholars.--A lady well qualified to teach Music on the Piano Forte would receive a few pulpits for instruction.
Apply at
div3.closer:
Mr. C Waldrop's,
North corner Leigh and Adams sts. se 10--eod3t*

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--I wish to purchase a negro woman, as seamstress and nurse.
A liberal price will be paid for one who can come well recommended for honesty, industry and capacity.
Apply to me at the Adj't and Insp Gen's office, or Mr. Starke's, on Grace st, near the old Fair Grounds.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--In a private family in the city, a teacher to instruct two childen in English, French and Latin.
Address "J E," Dispatch office.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p: --Servant.--I wish to purchase or hire a dinning room servant of suitable qualifications and of good character.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--By a young lady with some experience as a teacher, whose home is in the enemy's lines, a situation in a family or school.
She is qualified to teach French, Latin, the usual English branches, and the rudimehts of Music.--Best of reference given.
For further particulars, please address immediately
div3.closer:
John W Rison. Druggist,
Box 952, Richmond, Va. se 8--6t*

div3.head: Lost
div3.p:
--Confederate Certificate.--Lost by me, on the 1st day of June, 1863, near Raccoon Ford, on the Rappahannock river, Va, a Confederate Certificate of Deposit, No. 97, dated 4th of April, 1863,issued in my name, for $400, on account of the February 7 per cent loan.
The public are cautioned against trading for the same, as notice has been given to the Department and application made for a duplicate.

div3.head: Stolen
div3.p:
--$300 Reward.--Stolen from the residence of the subscriber, on the night of the 11th inst, $57 in Confederate money, nearly all $20 notes; also, a black Coat and Pants.
The coat has my name in the left sleeve, and it is also in the pants under the watch pocket.
I will give $100 reward for the above, and $200 additional for the conviction of the thief.

div3.head: Fifty Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Stolen from my stable in Sidney, near Camp Lee, on Friday night, a sorrel Mare.
She has a white speck in her forehead and two white specks on her back, caused from saddle galls.
She has one white hind foot.
I will pay the above reward for her return to me or information so I get her again.

div3.head: Strayed
div3.p:
--From my premises, on the 7th day of Sept., two Hogs, about one year old; one black, and the other yellow, with black spots.
Any person who has taken them up, or can give information that will lead to their recovery, will be well rewarded by
div3.closer:
John Brophy,
Corner of 15th and Marshall sts. se 14--1t*

div3.head: Strayed
div3.p: --From the front of the Post Office, (last night about dark,) a medium size light bay Horse, with saddle and bridle on. A suitable reward and all expenses will be paid for his delivery to me, on corner of Leigh and 6th streets.

div3.head: Strayed or stolen
div3.p: --On the morning of the 12th inst, a medium sized dark bay mare Mule, branded on her jaw with the letter "O," A suitable reward will be paid for her or for any information that will lead to her recovery.

div3.head: Fifty Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Strayed from the Tredegar Iron Works, on Thursday night, 10th inst, two large bay mare Mules, in tolerably good order; a little thin; manes and tails not closely trimmed.
The above reward will be paid for their return to us, or for any information that will lead to their recovery.
As these Mules were recently purchased near Tappahannock, it is probable they may undertake to return to that place

div3.head: Strayed
div3.p:
--On Monday night last, from near City Point, Goochland county, a bay Horse, with the letter "C" on his left hip, and one hind foot white.
I will give $15 reward for his delivery to me, or any information so that I can get him.
div3.closer:
Jas M Pierce,
Goochland Court-House. se 11--3t*

div3.head: Estray Cows.
div3.p:
--Came to my house, about the 1st inst, near Camp Winder, two stray Cows; one red, the other white and red spotted.
The owner is requested to prove property pay charges, and take them away.

div3.head: Two hundred Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Strayed or stolen, on Cary st, in rear of M Blair's, corner of 12th st, one black Horse, with one white hind foot and star in forehead, and cavalry Saddle, Bridle, and Halter on. I will pay the above reward for the delivery of the horse, saddle, and bridle to Mr. C J Hatcher, corner 9th and Main sts, or to Jno F Stagg, at Major.
D H Wood's office, on Bank st, or to me, 136 Cary st.

div3.head: Two hundred Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Stolen on or about the 16th of August, on the Manchester road, from the farm of Mr. Woltaire, five miles from the city, a roan horse, blaze face, three white feet, large frame, wounded on the backbone immediately under the saddle, the scar still visible.
The horse was well known through the whole army as belonging to the late Lieut Col. G Coppens.
Any information that will lead to the recovery of said horse will be gratefully received, and the above reward will be given.
Address
div3.closer:
Lieut Col. A Coppens,
Spotswood Hotel. se 7--6t*

div4.p: --The concern of Ellett, Bell & Co was dissolved by mutual consent on the 5th inst. The name of the concern will be used only in liquidation.

div4.head: New concern.
div4.p: --The undersigned, members of the late firm of Ellett, Bell & Co, will continue the general Auction, Commission, and Jobbing business, at the old stand, No. 17 Pearl street, under the style and firm of Ellett, Bell & Fox, soliciting consignments of general merchandize.

Tardy & Williams, corner of Cary and 13th streets, Richmond, Va, continue their general Auction and Commission business at their large warehouse, located as above, and solicit consignments of Groceries, Tobacco, Liquors, and all kinds of Merchandize and Produce.

div3.head: The
div3.p: undersigned having formed a co-partnership will conduct the lumber and wood business, at the corner 15th and Dock sts, under the style of Whitlock & Roane.

div3.head: Winter Seed Oats.--
div3.p:
800 bushels superior Winter Seed Oats, in lots to suit purchasers.
Particular attention of farmers is called to these Oats.
They are clean and nice.
Also--50 bushels nice Country Meal, fresh from the mill;
Family Bacon and Lard;
Pure Cider Vinegar, for pickling.
div3.closer:
For sale by Pulliam, Hanes & Weisiger,
Odd Fellows's Hall. se 14--2t*

div3.head: Later from the North.
div3.p:
The Baltimore American, of the 10th, has been received.
It contains very little news.

A telegram from Cincinnati, dated the 9th, says that Gen. Crittenden's division, of Gen. Rosecan's army, took possession of Chattanooga on that day. The Confederates evacuated the town on the 8th, retreating Southward.

An arrival at Philadelphia brings news from Vera Cruz to the 15th ult. The occupation of Tampico by the French was effected after a slight resistance.
The French forces also occupied Tuceleamingo.
Miramon has given in his adhesion to the new order of things.
Another rebellion is reported to have broken out at San Dinacupo.
The yellow fever is raging in Havana to a considerable extent.

The New York stock market was excited on the 9th.
Gold quoted at 132 Virginia sixes 57; North Carolina's 66, Tennessee's 65.

div4.head: Still later.
div4.p: We have received Baltimore papers of Saturday, 12th inst., containing the following:

div5.head: From Tennessee.

q.p:
The great campaign of the war is over.
We are in full possession of East Tennessee.
It is a great but bloodless victory.
The whole march of our army was a perfect ovation, and our entry into Knoxville an event long to be remembered.

div5.p: Thousands of people of every age, size, color and condition, lined the way, with shouts and tears, intermingled with martial music, and joy reigned supreme.
Burnside's address to his soldiers and the people assured them of protection, and that, while justice should be dealt, revenge was no part of the policy of the Government.
Col. Gilbert has been appointed Military Governor, and General Carter Provost-Marshal General of East Tennessee.
The following official report of General Burnside has been received:

div5.opener: Cumberland Gap, Sept. 9, 1863. Major-General Halleck, General-in-Chief:
div5.p:
I have telegraphed you of our movements up to the occupation of Knoxville by our forces.
Since then a cavalry force has been sent up the railroad to within a few miles of Bristol, capturing some three locomotives and twenty-odd cars.

Another force, composed of two regiments of infantry and two of cavalry, I brought to this place in person to reinforce Gen. Shackelford, who was here with two regiments of cavalry, Col. DeCourey being on the Kentucky side with a brigade which I started in that direction before leaving Kentucky.
The infantry brigade marched from Knoxville to this place, sixty miles, in fifty-two hours. The garrison here, consisting of over 2,000 men and 14 pieces of artillery, made an unconditional surrender at 3 o'clock P. M. today, without a fight.

A dispatch from Gen. Rosecrans, dated camp near Trenton, Ga., Sept. 9th, 8.30 P. M., says Chattanooga is ours without a struggle and East Tennessee is free.
Our move on the enemy's flank and rear progresses, while the tail of his retreating column will not escape unmolested.
Our troops from this side entered Chattanooga about noon.
Those north of the river there are crossing.

div4.head: From Texas.
div4.p: New Orleans dates to the 6th inst., via Cairo, had been received.

An officer from Brashear city states that a deserter from a Texas regiment, who came in on Sunday, reports that an order had been read to the troops, by order of Gen. Dick Taylor, that Gen. Magruder was killed in Galveston the week previous by one of his Lieutenants, who had caught him in a criminal act with his wife.

The deserter also stated that the whole rebel force in Louisiana is not over 10,000 men, scattered from Brashear city to Opelousas and Alexandria, under command of Taylor, whose headquarters are at Alexandria.

The regiment to which the deserter belonged had nearly all deserted.
Two more regiments were in open mutiny.
[The whole story is doubtless a fiction.]

div4.head: Important from Mexico.
div4.p: Dates from the City of Mexico, via San Francisco, to the 15th instant, have been received:

q.p: Miramon had been appointed by Gen. Forey commander of the Mexican forces.

bibl.n: The City of Mexico, via San Francisco

div4.p: The Triumvirate had notified the representatives of foreign Governments that a legal Government had been provided for Mexico, and they had been requested to recognize the Triumvirate as constituting such Government.
The American and Central American Ministers replied that they must recognize the Juarez Government until further instructions from their Governments.
Comonfort and Doblado had published strong appeals urging the Mexicans to continue to respect' the French.

div4.head: Miscellaneous.
div4.p:
It is reported on the authority of an escaped Federal soldier that the Confederates, under Price and Marmaduke, were evacuating.
Little Rock, Arkansas, with the intention of making a stand at Washington.
Their numbers are now estimated at not more than 8,000 men.

Judge Calwallader, of Philadelphia, has decided in a case recently argued before him that the right of Congress to pass the conscription act is legally and constitutionally derived from the clause of the Constitution, giving Congress the power to raise armies, etc.

The Baltimore Republican has been suppressed by order of Gen. Schenck, and its editors and proprietors sent across the lines, with peremptory orders that if they returned during the war they would be treated as spies.

Last Thursday Archbishop Purcell left Cincinnati for the purpose of visiting the Southern Confederacy.
He will pass through Rosecrans's lines, and go to Mobile first.

A dispatch from Columbus says that, recruiting having failed to fill up the quota of Ohio, an order has been received from Washington to enforce the draft.
The number of men to be raised is 12,000, requiring the use of 18,000 names.
The draft will begin at Cincinnati next week.

A fire Friday morning destroyed the boiler works, blacksmith shop, and machine shop of the Globe Iron Works, of South Boston.
The accident will cause a delay in the construction of the two new monitors building there.

Minister Adams, in his latest dispatches, says that he is still of the opinion that the rebel rams, against the departure of which the Emancipation Society has recently memorialized the English Government, will be permitted to sail.

Exciting reports are in circulation in Kansas of another invasion of that State by Quantrell, who has at least 1,000 men near the Kansas line.
Mayor Anthony, of Leavenworth, who was arrested by order of Gen. Ewing, has been released.

The Democratic nominations in New York are: Secretary of State, D. B. St. John; Comptroller, Sanford E. Church; Attorney-General, M. B. Champlin; State Engineer, Nan R. Richmond; Treasurer, Wm. B. Lewis; Canal Commissioner, W. W. Wright; Judge of Court of Appeals, Wm. F. Allen.
Col. D. M. Strother, (Porte Crayon,) of the 3d Virginia Yankee cavalry, boasts in the papers of repulsing a rebel cavalry attack at Bath, Va.
The British prize steamer at present in New York harbor, has been purchased by the War Department.

div3.head: A Modest demand.
div3.p: --A number of the pilots on the Alabama river, have struck for higher wages, demanding $600 per month.--in consequence of this there are but few boats running.

p.hi: further particulars — additional particulars of the evacuation of Morris Island, &c.

div4.p:
The Charleston papers of Thursday bring us the particulars of the repulse of the enemy in their assault on Fort Sumter Wednesday.
The assault was not made without a demand by the enemy for the surrender of the fort, which is stated in the following correspondence:
A flag of truce from Admiral Dahlgren, demanding the surrender of this fort, has been received by Lieut. Brown, of the Palmetto State.

div4.opener: Headq'rs, Sept. 7, 1863. To this the following reply was sent:
div4.p: Inform Admiral Dahlgren that he may have Fort Sumter when he can take and hold it; that such demands are puerile and unbecoming; also, that no further flags of truce will be received from him or General Gillmore until they satisfactorily explain their firing on flags of truce from these headquarters on several recent occasions.

div4.opener: To Major Stephen Elliott, Major commanding Fort Sumter.
div4.p: The Mercury, of Thursday gives the following account of the assault and its repulse:

q.p:
For several nights past it is known that expeditions in barges have been sent out from the fleet to reconnoitre the inner harbor and prepare the way for an assault upon Fort Sumter.
The manner in which these expeditions are organized may be understood from the following orders which we select as instances, from a budget of similar Yankee official documents which have fallen into our hands:

div4.head: Flag steamer Philadelphia,
div4.opener: Off Morris Island, Sept. 4th, 1863. Lieut.-Commander E. P. Williams, Commanding U. S. S. Wissahickon: Sir:
div4.p: You will proceed, without delay, to organize a volunteer party of not more than (200) two hundred men, under proper officers, for special service.
You will also procure a sufficient number of boats to transport them; the whole to be inside the bar at an early hour this evening.

The commanding officers of the vessels off Charleston are hereby directed, on the presentation of this order, to furnish you the number of boats, men and officers that may be allotted as the proportion to come from their vessels.
Signal No. 72 will annul this.
div4.closer:
Respectfully, your obd't serv't, J. H. Dahlgren,
Rear Admiral Commanding
South Atlantic Blockading Squadron.

div4.head: Order.
div4.p: Lieutenant-Commander E. P. Williams is instructed to organize a force of sailors for special service — and the commanding officers of the following vessels will place under his command — men (volunteers preferred) and boats properly officered as follows:
If the Canandaigua arrives off the bar in time Captain Green will send 40 men and 3 boats.
div4.closer:
Very respectfully, J. H. Dahlgren,
R. Admiral Commanding,
S. A. B. Squadron.

div4.p:
It was by one of these barge expeditions that the boat sent to Morris Island for Major Warley was captured.
This information is of an authentic character.
Major Warley is safe, but a prisoner in the hands of the enemy.

At about half-past 1 o'clock yesterday morning the prevailing quiet was rudely broken by a sudden and very rapid cannonade in the direction of the harbor entrance.
The brief intervals between the reports of the heavy guns were filled by the roll of musketry, and all who heard the firing in the city thought that warm work had begun at Fort Sumter.
It appears, from the accounts that we have received, that at half-past 1 A. M. yesterday, a number of barges, variously estimated at from twenty to thirty, and containing about fifty men each, were descried through the darkness pulling rapidly to wards the fort.
They were steered towards various portions of the ledge of rocks outside the fort, (known, technically, we believe, as the berm,) but most of them directed their course, towards the gorge face, which, being now a sloping mass of bricks and rubbish, seemed to afford the most inviting opportunity for the assault.

As soon as the barges were seen by our vigilant sentries on the parapet three rockets were thrown up to notify their comrades at the other batteries of the danger at hand.--With commendable alacrity the guns of Fort Johnson, battery Simkins, Fort Moultrie, and the steamer Chicora, opened upon the barges, and simultaneously the infantry, judiciously posted within the fort, poured into the crowded boats of the assailants a rapid and spirited fire of musketry.
The foremost boats of the enemy, however, soon gained the ledge, and the Yankees sprang to the assault with vigor and determination.
They were met, however, by resolute men. The Charleston battalion, Major Blake commanding, had been advantageously posted at the threatened points, and repelled the foe with a gallantry worthy the name which the battalion won so dearly at Secessionville, and afterwards at battery Wagner.
When their muskets had been discharged, instead of losing precious time in reloading, they buried hand grenades against the foe, and when these were exhausted, had recourse to the brick bats which lay everywhere around them, and rained them down the slope.

This storm of miscellaneous missiles was too much for the storming party, and the forlorn hope fled in confusion to the base of the fort.
Meantime the barges in the rear, terror stricken by the severe concentrated fire they had encountered, had abandoned the attack and gone off, leaving the Yankees who had landed wholly without support.
It is scarcely necessary to add that these last, foiled in their effort to surprise the garrison, and not daring to take to their boats, surrendered at discretion, and announced the fact in tones which could be heard high above the splashing of the waves and the din of the engagement.
The receding barges were soon lost to sight in the darkness, the prisoners were marched into the fort and secured, and silence again reigned in the harbor.

In this brilliant repulse of the enemy we captured thirteen Yankee naval officers and 102 men, besides three stands of colors, four fine barges, etc. Among the flags taken was the original (United States) flag of Fort Sumter, which floated over the work at the time when Major Anderson held command there.
Upon the surrender of the fort in April, 1861, it will be remembered, Major Anderson was allowed to salute, haul down, and carry off this identical flag.
Admiral Dahlgren, it seems, had undertaken to "repossess" the fort, and to "restore the old flag" to the flag-staff from which South Carolina tore it at the opening of the war. But the poetic justice of the Admiral's scheme has not saved the scheme itself from collapse; and whatever may be the fate of Fort Sumter in the future, that "old flag" will surely never again wave over its walls.

Of the enemy's loss in killed and wounded we have no authentic account.
Two of them were found dead at the fort and nineteen wounded; but from the fact that several barges, riddled by shot, have been seen floating about, capsized, many believe that the enemy's loss was much greater.
It is rumored that the naval officer named Meade, who was captured, is a son of Gen. Meade, the successor of Hooker.
On our side there was no casualty of any kind during the fight.

We captured in all 115 men belonging to the U. S. Navy, or Marine Corps.
Amongst them were the following officers:
E. P. Williams, commanding gunboat Wissahickon.
Robt. L. Meade, Lt. U. S. Marines.
C. P. Hovey, Master Mate U. S. steamer Powhatan.
Benjamin H. Porter, Ensign U. S. frigate New Ironsides.
Edwin T. Brewer, Lieut. U. S. sloop-of-war Housatonic.
Lieut. S. W. Preston, U. S. Admiral Flagship Philadelphia.
Lieut. Geo. C. Roamey, gunboat Canandaigua.
Ensign S. C. McCanley, gunboat Canandaigua.
Lieut. Chas. H. Bradford, U. S. Marines wounded.
E. G. Dayton, Executive Officer on board the gunboat Wissahickon.
The prisoners reached the city last night and were marched through the city, under strong guard, to the jail.

During yesterday, the enemy's guns were almost wholly silent.
The Yankees are evidently working hard at Cummings's Point, where they have strengthened and enlarged our works.
They are also bringing up their heavy ordnance (Parrott guns, we suppose,) to be placed at that point.
Last night our batteries were keeping up a steady fire upon the enemy's newly acquired positions, and as we go to press the reports are still heard at regular intervals.

The Mercury gives some additional particulars of the evacuation of Morris Island.
It says:

q.p:
The barges containing the troops all left the island in safety, but it is now ascertained that three of them were captured.
Of these, two were army barges and contained about fifteen men each; the other was a barge belonging to the Chicora, and contained no troops, excepting the boat's crew from the Chicora.
For nearly two hours after the last of our barges had pushed off from the beach, the enemy kept up a heavy fire from their land batteries against batteries Wagner and Gregg and along the intervening beach.
At the end of that time it is supposed they began to suspect that they were shelling abandoned works, for their fire rapidly slackened, and soon ceased altogether.
Soon after four o'clock they crossed the sand parapet, which had so long defied their fleets and artillery, and took possession of battery Wagner.

div4.p:
The 54th Massachusetts (negro) regiment was placed there to garrison the post, and their regimental colors — the State flag of Massachusetts--was soon waving over the battery.
The enemy, however, were not suffered long to hold their newly acquired domain in quiet.
Before day Fort Moultrie had opened upon them from the opposite side of the harbor, and the indefatigable gunners of battery Simkins had turned their pieces against the now hostile precincts of Wagner.
During the morning a party of mounted Yankee officers galloped along the beach towards battery Gregg and rode upon the parapet of that work, gazing into the harbor and at the city, which they doubtless have come to regard as a "promised land." Their meditations were soon rudely interrupted by a shell from Capt. Mitchell's battery.
As the shell burst one of the number was seen to fall from his horse, and the others scampered from their lookout with the most undignified haste.

div3.head: Charged with Horse stealing.
div3.p:
--Samuel J Shepperson was arraigned before the Mayor yesterday morning, charged with taking, some time since, and selling, a pair of horses belonging to Mrs. Mary E. Andrews, of Spotsylvania county, Va. Shepperson acknowledged having sold one of the horses, but claimed to have done so as agent only for Mr. James P. Tyler, of Henrico county.--These circumstances partially shifted the charge from S. to that gentleman, who was then called upon to explain how they came into his possession.
This he did by the testimony of Mr. George P. Tyler, his brother, and another soldier, who testified that on the 9th or 10th of August, they were at Jas. Tyler's on a visit from the army, and while there a man named Jennings came up and sold him the horses.
The man immediately afterwards left and had not been heard from since.
At this stage of the proceedings the Mayor adjourned the examination till Wednesday next, in order to have present a very material witness for the Commonwealth.--Shepperson was discharged from all guilt, but held to bail to appear as a witness.
Tyler was bailed to appear for examination in the sum of $700. A. Judson Crane, Esq., appeared as counsel for Tyler.

div3.head: Drunk and Disorderly.
div3.p:
--Jas. Derney alias James W. Bowman, attended a ball at Emerson's hotel on Thursday night last and there imbibed too much of the fiery liquid.
In the course of the evening he gave an exhibition of his vocal powers in the street, which met with an objection from some of the night watch in that section of the city.
Derney became very indignant at this want of appreciation of good music, and bestowed upon them in return a tirade of abuse, accompanied with a threat to "blow their brains out," which resulted in his arrest and lodgment in the watch-house for the night.
Some doubts existing as to the previous good character of the accused, coupled with the fact that there was found in his possession a pair of pincers used for picking locks, induced the Mayor to send him on for indictment before the next term of the Hustings Court Grand Jury in November next, and he was held in bonds in the sum of $500.

div3.head: Dismissed.
div3.p:
--Wm. Banks, a free negro, was caught in the street on Friday night last, beating a drum and without a proper pass.
His good character being certified to the Mayor discharged him.

A little boy, named James Sullivan, in company with some other boys, went into the gun store of Mr. James Walsh, on Main street, on Friday afternoon last, and took from his drawer a considerable sum of money.
In a short time after, finding that they were known, one of them returned and threw the money on the counter.
Sullivan was arrested on the charge of stealing it; but the Mayor, in consideration of the extreme youth of the lad, as well as from the fact that the money had been returned, dismissed him with an admonition to pursue an honest life in future.

div3.head: An abominable nuisance.
div3.p:
--The disgusting practice indulged in by some persons of smoking in the public markets of this city is one which should be put a stop to. Not only are some of the attendants at these places often seen with rusty old pipes in their mouths, but it not unfrequently happens that some of the hucksters themselves stick a pipe between their teeth when they first open their stands in the morning and never take it out till the close of the market.
If a gentle hint to these persons does not bring about a discontinuance of this nuisance, the Council would confer a great favor upon the ladies, and a large number of other citizens, by passing an ordinance imposing a heavy fine upon any one guilty of the offence of smoking in the market places.

div3.head: Without a license.
div3.p:
--A. Louse, a German keeping a saloon on Broad street, was before the Mayor on Saturday charged with having a billiard table over his bar-room at which the game is played, without a license.
Louse protested his ignorance of the law governing such games, when the Mayor informed him if he would go immediately to the Chamberlain and procure a license, and bring it to him, he would thereby be influenced with regard to the amount of fine he should impose on him. This he did, and was dismissed with simply the payment of the costs incurred in the case.

div3.head: A Cute Trick.
div3.p:
--We were shown on Saturday last a Confederate one dollar note which had been altered to a two.
The left hand corner of the two dollar note had been neatly cut off so as to embrace the whole of that part having "two" printed on it, which was pasted in the place of the "one" occupying the same position in the one dollar note.--The word "one" running across the centre was carelessly torn out, and the figure "I" at the right hand top corner was also pinched off. There may be others of this kind in circulation, and we would advise persons to be particular in examining these twos of the old issue.

div3.head: Died of lockjaw.
div3.p: --An interesting little girl named Annie, daughter of Mr. Jeremiah Coughlin, living on Marshall, near 6th st., stuck a nail in her foot on Wednesday last, which terminated in death from lockjaw on Thursday noon. Her death is represented to have been one of intense agony.

div3.head: Narrow escape.
div3.p:
--Yesterday morning a difficulty occurred at the American Hotel between two boys, one white and the other black, which resulted in the white one drawing a knife and pursuing the negro, who jumped from the inside second story window down to the sky light immediately over the passage leading to the ladies' entrance to the dining room.
The glass covering to the skylight broke through, but fortunately the negro boy extended his arms in time to catch hold of the sides of the hole in the roof in which the glass had been inserted.
The distance from the second story window to the sky-light is about fifteen feet, and from that to the first floor about ten feet more.
No injury was sustained by the negro.

div3.head: Postponed.
div3.p:
--The examination of Wm. H. Travis, charged with shooting his wife, was again deferred by the Mayor on Saturday last till next Friday, on account of the inability of Mrs. T. to appear and testify.
Her physicians represent her as improving rapidly, and thought by that time she would be able to go out.

Christian Burgan was arraigned on the charge of receiving three bags of corn from a negro, knowing the same to have been stolen.
A witness testified that the negro had taken it from the Government stables at Bacon's Quarter Branch.
The Mayor continued the case till Monday, and bailed the accused in the sum of $500 to appear and answer.

Thomas Bird, a free negro, arrested for stealing a horse, will undergo an examination on Saturday.
Mr. George Dabney Wootten, counsel for Bird, made an earnest appeal to His Honor to bail his client; he was confident of proving the negro's innocence, and did not see why he should not be permitted to go at large till the trial.
The Mayor refused to comply and Thomas was committed to jail.

div3.head: Market prices.
div3.p:
--The following prices prevailed at the Second Market Saturday morning for the articles enumerated:--Green corn $1.50 per dozen, black eye peas 50 cents per quart, butter beans $1 per quart, sweet potatoes $1.50 per quart, Irish do. 50c per quart, cabbage 50ca$4.50 per head, tomatoes 25a75c per dozen, egg plant 75a$1.25 apiece, snaps 75ca$1 per quart, beets 50c per bunch of six or eight, okra 50c per quart, pumpkins $1.50a2.50 apiece, watermelons 75ca$5, muskmelons 25ca$1.25 apiece, grapes 50c per bunch of about half a pint, chickens from $1 to $3 apiece, ducks $5 per pair, beef $1.25 per pound, veal $1.25, lamb $1a1.25, mutton $1a1.25, smoked sausage $1.25, beef tallow $2 per pound, common bacon two dollars and a half per pound, (an abominable extortion,) shoat $1.50 per pound, salt shad $3a3.75 apiece, salt herrings (none good in market) $3a3.50 per dozen, soap (country) $1a1.25.
The market was well supplies, but, as the above prices will show, everything was very high.

div3.head: A bad character.
div3.p:
--A little girl, named Melissa J. Palmature, was brought before the Mayor, Saturday, charged with stealing $190 in C. S. notes from the coat-pocket of Dozier M. Hughes.
Melissa had gone in a store on Broad st., and collected from Mr. Hughes five dollars, upon the representation that her mother and sisters were in a suffering condition.
Hughes was about washing his hands, and had thrown his coat on the counter, and the girl having seen him go to it and take from his pocket-book the money which he gave her, it is supposed this was the way in which she found out where it was kept.
The Mayor, recognizing her as a girl of had reputation, sent her on to the Hustings Court, which sits this morning.

div3.head: Whipped.
div3.p: --Bartlett, slave of John H. Parker, was ordered a whipping by the Mayor for having in his possession a piece of oil cloth supposed to have been stolen.
William, belonging to Edward Browning, was ordered fifteen lashes for beating a drum in the street on Friday night last.
A thrashing was also awarded Sam, the property of G. W. Robertson, for stealing six sides of sole leather and one bag of coffee, belonging to the C. S. Government.

div3.head: All right.
div3.p:
--Before the weekly dress parade of the departmental battalion took place, Friday afternoon, the Reagan Guards had a drill meeting, ordered especially for the inspection of arms.
The company appeared in full numbers, presenting a fine military appearance, their highly burnished arms exhibiting a most gratifying spectacle of great industry since the late memorable campaign at Stewart's farm.

div3.head: The cage.
div3.p:
--The following parties were yesterday committed to the cage, to be heard before His Honor the Mayor this morning: Harriet, slave of J. W. Blake, charged with stealing between $3,000 and $4,000, the property of her master; and Caroline, slave of Lucinda Pilcher, charged with receiving the same, knowing it to have been stolen.
They were arrested by officers Seal and Ward.

div3.head: A severe fall.
div3.p:
--On Friday afternoon last a soldier, while under the influence of liquor, fell from the abutment of the Petersburg Railroad Bridge, on this side of the river, breaking one of his legs and sustaining some internal injury.
We were unable to learn his name or to what regiment he belonged.

div3.head: The War upon women in Maryland.
div3.p:
The Provost guard in Carroll county, Md., has commenced the arrest of women, having already arrested pretty nearly every man of any position in the county, on suspicion of disloyalty.
The West master Democrat says:

q.p:
On Wednesday and Friday of last week, matters took a different turn, and some fifteen or twenty ladies daily received written notices from Lieut. Beman, Military Provost Marshal, requesting them to report at his headquarters.
In some instances whole families were summoned.
The first ladies thus summoned made quite a stir in the community — in a quiet way — to ascertain the object and result of such arrests.
The public curiosity was at length gratified, and not a little disappointed.
The charges were various, but finally settled down upon the general issue, "Feeding the rebels," "general disloyalty, " "c. The oath of allegiance, the penances for such offences, was tendered, when many of the ladies accused asked the consequences if they refused to take it.--They were informed that they would be immediately sent to the county jail; under this threat they took the oath and were discharged.
Several gentlemen were also requested to report: among them was Dr. Geo. H. Trumbo, who, being unwilling to take the oath, was confined in the county jail until Saturday morning, when he was taken to Baltimore and sent to Donnovan's prison to await an examination.
The Sun, of Monday, stated that he is charged with "uttering disloyal language and persecuting certain Union men of Westminster." On Monday last one lady was brought in from-the country, who took the oath and was discharged.

div3.head: Theatrical.
div3.p: --The London Star, of the 27th ult., says:

q.p:
On Wednesday the steamer City of New York carried out to New York, amongst her passengers, Miss Bella Vaughan, an article who has gained much celebrity by her performances at the principal provincial theatres, and especially by her recent personification of Lady Audley, in the play of "Lady Audley's Secret," Mr. Gomersall and Mr. and Mrs. De Vere, of the Liverpool Royal and Amphitheaters.
Those ladies, and gentlemen have been engaged by the lessee of the Richmond Theatre, Virginia; but how they are to reach the Capital of the Confederacy, after their arrival in New York, is a mystery.

div3.head: Gillmore's reply to Beauregard.
div3.p:
--Much curiosity has been manifested to learn the tenor of Gillmore's reply to Beauregard.
I learn, says the Charleston correspondent of the Mobile Tribune, that Gillmore retorted by saying that Gen. Beauregard was fully aware of the length of time the city had been under siege, and of the lapse of time since the commencement of the bombardment, so that if he did not give notice to non-combatants to leave, it was his own fault; that as to Gen. Beauregard's threat of retaliation, he treated it with scorn, and that he concluded by expressing his fullest confidence as to what must he the final result of the siege.
