div3.head: Rage wanted.
div3.p: --Fifteen and Twenty Cents per Pound (according to quality) will be paid at this office for all kinds of Clean Cotton and Linen Rags, in large or small quantities.

div3.head: Has the War vindicated Yankee heroism?
div3.p: --If it were possible that, amid the din of war, the calm voice of reason could be heard by Yankee ears, we would invoke the Yankee nation, from its Executive at Washington to the meanest clod-hopper on the prairies, to lay its hand upon its heart, or the place where that organ ought to be, and answer us what real cause there is for its vociferous exultation over the late successes of its arms, even conceding them to be successes, and what the world must think of a nation which runs stark mad with delight because, after a war of two years, and with odds of four to one, it has sometimes gained a victory?

Let us take an illustration which any clod-hopper can understand.
Four big, burly fellows make an assault upon a small man, and after a long fight, in which the plucky little fellow knocks one or the other of the ruffians down a dozen times, they succeed in flooring him once or twice, and thereupon they set up such a shout of triumph as makes the welkin ring, and appoint a day of thanks-giving and prayer for their wonderful success!
Yankee, what in your inmost soul — or in the place where a soul ought to be — would you think of those four?
Would not their very exultation be a glorying in their shame?
Would not their yells of triumph be actually a tribute to the courage of their enemy, and confession of their own inferiority?

We have never believed that slavery had as much to do with this war as personal resentment and vindictiveness, transmitted from generation to generation, smouldering embers of the old Cavalier and Puritan feuds, which had never died out. The descendants of those two classes in the North and the South would have gone to war, sooner or later, if such a thing as slavery had never existed.
We do not include all the North in the Puritan, any more than all the South in the Cavalier classification, but that is the predominant element in each.
Slavery is but the occasion of the strife, and its real provocations are the envy, malice, hatred, and all uncharitableness, which have characterized the deportment of Puritanism towards its political and ecclesiastical superiors from the beginning of its existence.

Perhaps, of all the barbed weapons cast on both sides before this war, none has rankled so deeply in Puritan hearts as the imputation of cowardice.
It mattered not that the imputation was not generally cast upon the North by Southern men, and that there were many of us who emphatically vindicated their character from the charge.
But they never forgave it, and we verily believe that second only, if second at all, to the intense fanaticism of abolitionism, was the burning desire of the Northern people to clear their escutcheon of the blot of cowardice and achieve renown for chivalry and progress in arms.

Now, we ask them in all soberness if they think they have succeeded?
We, for one, never doubted their courage up to the period of this war. We always entertained as profound a conviction that Cromwell and his followers were bold men as that they were bad men. We had often dwelt with pride upon the exploits of Northern naval commanders in the Revolution and the late war. But this struggle!
this uprising of the giant against the dwarf!
this huge Titan, hurling rocks not against the gods, but against a defenceless dweller in the plains, and calling upon all the powers of earth and hell to aid him in the contest — call you this chivalry?
or, even if he should succeed, glory?

What have they done?
They began by vociferating in the halls of Congress that eighteen millions of people could easily crush eight.
Is that their conception of chivalry?
They were not satisfied with the vast numerical preponderance, but they scoured the earth for reinforcements, filling their armies with Irishmen and Germans to establish Yankee courage!
They have called into the field, from first to last, more than a million of men. They had at the start all the regular army; all the old navy; all the machinery and mechanism of war; all the shipping of the country; all the workshops, manufactories, and commerce, besides access for men and munitions of war to all the nations of the earth, whilst we, with none of these advantages, have been shut out from all nations.
Surely, with such odds in their favor, whatever else their success in this war might prove, it would never vindicate that which they are most eager to establish--Yankee pluck and prowess.

What have these people to brag of?
They never gained a victory which was not gained by the most enormous superiority in numbers and appliances of war. Their boasted General, Grant, at Donelson and Vicksburg, what did he do, but, after the most laborious and protracted efforts, with the gunboats and resources of the whole United States, added to a land force of three to one, overcome a feeble and poorly equipped band of heroes, who at last surrendered not to him but to starvation?
Is it such achievements as these that make the Wellington or Napoleons of the world?
What nation has ever yet established a name for heroism; what old warrior ever frowned in the brass or marble of Greece and Rome; what trophied monument or tower ever rose to the memory of a chief, who gained his victories by the aid of three or four to one?
It is not the countless host of Persians, but the three hundred at Thermopylæ to whom every human heart raises a temple, and whose deeds flame over successive generations like the blaze of a light-house over the waves of the sea, rescuing from darkness even the hostile billows which sought its destruction.

No! The Yankees may take every seaport town of the South; they may drive us to our mountain fastnesses; they may exterminate the last hero in the land, but they can never take from us, nor achieve for themselves, that which they so pant after — renown for courage and chivalry.
By huge machinery of muscle, bone and iron, by incalculable preponderance of numbers, by Germans, Irish and, at last, by negroes, whom it avows to be a "military necessity," the Yankee nation may achieve still further successes over a small and struggling people.
But this one thing can it never do — achieve renown for heroism.
No renown except such as the New York Herald and New York Tribune can confer,

will it ever obtain.
The nation that can clap its hands, and spread its wings, and crow like chanticleer over an occasional victory, gained by four to one, entitles itself to the supreme contempt of all mankind.
Not the American Eagle should henceforth decorate its banner, but a huge Turkey Cock, vain-glorious of "gobbling" every smaller creature, and "skedaddling" in hot haste from every adversary of equal size and power.

div3.head: Correction of an Error.
div3.p:
--In our remarks upon the National Loan of France we confounded it with the Credit Mobilier. We understand they are two distinct and widely different affairs, the latter being a tax on moveables.
We erred from sheer ignorance, and nothing else.

div3.head: From Tennessee.
div3.p:
The intelligence from Tennessee is very misty.
The commanding General there has very properly embargoed all intelligence relative to the military movements going on in that State.
On the 3d inst., Gen. Forrest gave the enemy a severe drubbing at Kingston, killing and wounding a large number of them.
Kingston is a small county town, located upon the banks of the Tennessee and Clinch rivers, eighteen miles below Loudon.
Gen. Forrest commenced crossing his command by ferry boats over the Tennessee river.
While crossing over with the last detachment, the ferry boat sunk, drowning ten men. The remainder swam ashore.
The following from the Marietta Confederate will show how the enemy is prosecuting hostilities in Tennessee:

The Yankees occupied Winchester on the 3d of July, celebrated the 4th, and issued a number of the Winchester Daily Bulletin on that day, taunting the editor and proprietor, Mr. Slatter, with supplying his place in his absence.
Gen. McCook occupied the residence of Mark Henderson as his headquarters, and Gen. Jeff. C. Davis (who killed Bull Nelson, the Kentucky Yankee General, last year,) occupied the residence of Harrison T. Carr, a member of the last Tennessee Legislator.
They put guards around the houses in town, and a few of them were robbed.
But they gave leave to their troops to wander up and down the country like devils, seeking what they might devour.
The consequence was that they carried on a system of general plunder, taking meat, meal, flour, and other provisions from all but the very poor, leaving nothing to eat, and making a large majority of the people wholly dependent on the enemy for rations, which were doled out to them for three days at a time.

They went to old Captain Taylor's, who is about ninety years old, and his son's, W. E. Taylor, formerly Clerk of the County Court, both of them regarded as rich men, and so completely robbed them that they had to subsist on boiled corn for more than a week, when they got a day's rations of meat and flour from a Yankee soldier, who took pity on them.

A brigade of troops was sent to the farm of A. Shook, a substantial citizen of seventy odd years, under the guidance of one of his negroes, and three regiments spent the day there.
They took all the provisions, not leaving half a gallon of meal for the old man and the family of his son, O. S. Shook, who had been in the First Tennessee regiment in Virginia.
They killed every hog, sheep, and calf that they could find, took five negro men — all he had — and three of them were armed, uniformed, and put in the Yankee service.
They stole Mrs. S. Shook's watch and jewelry, and afterwards a guard was put over her room.

Mrs. Shook went to town to draw rations.
The Provost Marshal was disposed to be courteous, but said she must go to General Davis.
She went to Davis's quarters, and his Adjutant or Clerk repeated the name; "Shook!
Shook!"--when Davis said, "All rebels; and you, madam, are as d — n a rebel as any." "Yes," said she, "and always will be." Davis said, "You can't get any rations." Mrs. S., "Do you intend me and my children to starve?
You have stolen all my meat and everything else to eat." He replied, "I don't care a d — n if you and your children do starve." He seemed familiar with the people's names, and called the names of all the men in the Shook family — the father and sons--one of whom was the Confederate Postmaster at Winchester, another in Starnes's cavalry, and the third, a lawyer, had been in the First regiment, as already stated.

It is said that so sweeping has been the pillaging and desolation, that not a shock of wheat has been left in the country, and they were cutting the green corn; and there are no vegetables, and not a sitting, hen, goose, or other fowl.
Notwithstanding this barbarous treatment, the spirits of the people are not broken, but they are still defiant and opposed to reconstruction of the old Union hulk.
The Yankee papers say that they have no friends in Franklin county, and complain that the ladies won't receive them in their parlors, saying that, if they would do so, they would find them a jovial set of fellows.

Notwithstanding the occupation of Franklin county by the Yankees, an election for members of the Legislature was held there on the 6th of August, the polls being opened within seven miles of Winchester, and John G. Enochs was elected Senator for Lincoln and Franklin, and Jas. K. Shook, Representative for Franklin, and certificates of election were awarded them.
A correspondent of the Charleston Mercury, writing from Charleston, Tenn., on the 3d inst., says:

q.p:
Our trains now run no further than Loudon, where the railroad crosses the Tennessee, and which is thirty miles from Knoxville.
Yesterday the enemy appeared at London, on the opposite bank, and shelled the place.
Our batteries responded, and our people burned the railroad bridge over the Tennessee.
This is a vast and splendid structure, worth a million of dollars.
Its destruction, alone, will cause the loss of the use of this railroad for many weeks.
The guns used must have been heavy ones, for I heard the cannonade at this place, though forty miles distant.

div3.p:
Yesterday and to-day this little village has been the scene of grand and moving sights.
For thirty-six hours past, night and day, there has been a continuous stream of wagons, long lines of infantry, leagues of cavalry and their diminutive batteries of artillery.
Thousands and tens of thousands of soldiers tramp, gallop, and hang about the streets; staff officers, couriers, orderlies, dash about on horseback; dust-covered dragoons lope along the streets, enveloped and obscured in the heavy clouds of impalpable dust; the entire village of Charleston is covered with great clouds of dust that envelope it like a heavy fog; dozens of locomotives are screaming and screeching, and long trains of cars speed down the road with tons of army stores; now and then a carriage load of fugitive ladies and children passes through to a place of refuge from Yankee outrage.
This morning I saw and conversed with the remnant of "Morgan's men," who escaped in the late raid.
They are several hundreds, and splendidly mounted, armed and equipped.
They are, indeed, almost the only cavalry in this army that ever fights with any spirit or success.

The enemy is reported in heavy force on the opposite bank of the river and as concentrating opposite this point, near the mouth of the Hiwassee.
I can hardly believe that he will take the hazards of crossing the river, but he must do either this of retreat.
He cannot long feed his army where it is, and to retreat would be a disgraceful and humiliating failure.

If he crosses, he comes to almost certain defeat and ruin; but he may be so blinded and flushed by recent victories as to rush thus madly on to destruction.
Ten days will be sufficient for both armies to get themselves together and to develop their plans.
And then, I suppose, comes "the tug of war."

div3.head: A Certificate of Morgan's having his head shaved.
div3.p: --From a late number of the Louisville Journal, sent by a friend, we extract the following:

We yesterday saw a military gentleman, just returned from Camp Chase, Ohio, who states that he saw Morgan while in Columbus last week, and that his head has surely been shaved.
His large whiskers, doubtless the pride of his sweet young wife, have also been cut off, and close to his face, too.

div3.head: The fight at Berkeley Springs.
div3.p:
--A few days since we published from Northern journals a brief account of an engagement at Berkeley Springs, Morgan county.
We have since obtained some particulars from a Southern source.--Capt. Blackford, with a squad of men, numbering about twenty-five, attacked the enemy at 3 o'clock in the morning of the 8th inst., and routed them completely, capturing twenty-nine prisoners, one negro, sixty horses, and some three hundred navy pistols — all of which they succeeded in bringing off in safety.
The prisoners had arrived at Staunton, on route for Richmond.
The enemy's force at the time the attack was made is said to have numbered some three hundred, but were taken by surprise, their pickets having been flanked.

div3.head: Raid on Wythe.
div3.p:
--A party of Yankees, numbering about sixty, started from Tazewell county, Va., on Thursday, on a horse stealing raid, in the direction of Wytheville.
They came from a band numbering about 400 which accompanied them as far as Burke's Garden, in Tazewell.
The sixty then started for Wytheville, but hearing of preparations made to receive them, returned to their comrades, and went back to Wyoming, where they all first started from.
Every man and boy able to bear a musket in Wythe county was out and ready for the raiders.
The little opposition heretofore met by the Yankees in these raids has caused them to pronounce the Confederacy a "shell." They will doubtless change their opinion.

div3.head: The Legislature.
div3.p:
--In the Senate, Saturday, two resolutions were submitted by Mr. Collier, in relation to desertion, the first declaring that there is sufficient severity in the death penalty for that offence, and that the efficiency of the army will be better promoted by the enforcement of that penalty than by any State legislation; the second requesting the representatives from this State, in the Confederate Congress to support such enactments as may be deemed requisite at the next session to secure the enforcement of the articles of war to prevent and punish desertion.
Under the rules these resolutions were laid over.

A large number of resolutions of inquiry were introduced, among them the following: By Mr. Alderson: Of suppressing the sale of all goods, wares and merchandize at public auction during the present war. By Mr. Newton: Of securing a fair and just distribution of salt among the citizens of the Commonwealth.
By Mr. Dickinson: Of amending the law in respect to exemptions, with a view of diminishing the number of exempts from military duty.
By Mr. Newman: Of requiring the Banks of the Commonwealth to receive on deposit Confederate States Treasury notes.
The joint resolution submitted some days ago by Mr. Johnson, of Bedford, relative to the Virginia and Tennessee railroad was taken up, and on motion of Mr. Neeson, referred.
The bills providing that all Confederate notes shall hereafter be received in payment of taxes was taken up and passed.
The Senate then went into secret session.

In the House, Mr. Bouldin, from the Committee on Finance, reported a bill making an appropriation for the expenditures of Government, and a bill to prevent public officers from speculating in Confederate notes.

The number of resolutions of inquiry submitted was large.
Among them we notice the following: By Mr. Hunter, of Berkeley — Of requiring all able-bodied foreigners to serve in the army or leave the State.
By Mr. Worsham--Of ascertaining what can be done, without detriment to the public interest, to allow the furloughs of soldiers to be regarded as passports on the railroads, &c., and so that loyal citizens may be relieved from the inconveniences of the present passport system.
By Mr. Holden--Of removing slaves from counties invaded by the public enemy.
By Mr. Winston--Of amending the existing law so as to require all polls taken in camp to be forwarded by mail when practicable.
By Mr. English--Of enrolling all male refugees domiciled in the State in the second class militia.
By Mr. Staples.--Of repealing the act providing for the discharge from active service of persons who have furnished substitutes.
By Mr. Robinson, of Berkeley — Of increasing the pay of employees of the State Government.
By Mr. Pendleton--Of suppressing all trade in gold and silver, the sale of Confederate notes or bank notes of the banks in the Confederate States for less or more than their stated value, and all traffic in the notes of the Federal Government, States and banks.
The two Houses, in joint session, then proceeded to count the vote for Governor and Lieutenant-Governor, which occupied the remainder of the day's session.

div3.head: Correction.
div3.p: --In our Legislative proceedings of Friday we erroneously stated that Mr. Dulaney, of Fairfax, "introduced a preamble and joint resolutions on the war, and its present aspect,"c. These resolutions were offered by Mr. Garrison, the Senator from Accomac.

div3.head: The two mobs in Raleigh — additional particulars.
div3.p:
The Raleigh (N. C.) Progress, of the 11th inst., furnishes an account of the proceedings of the two mobs which destroyed two newspaper offices in that city.
It is proper to state that the Progress is a "Buffalo" sheet, like the Standard, which was destroyed:

On Wednesday night, about 10 o'clock, a part of Benning's Georgia brigade--probably some fifty to one hundred men — apparently led by officers, passed up Fayetteville street, and halted at the Standard office.
They were armed, and carried torches.
Some of the officers went to Mr. Holden's house and inquired for that gentleman.
He appeared and invited them in; but, after assuring themselves they had found his residence, they withdrew, and soon the attack was made on the office by the armed men. The men did not seem to be excited or to manifest any passion, but went to gutting the office as they would have commenced the performance of any ordinary camp duty, all the movements being seemingly directed and carried on by officers.

The type were all thrown in the street or scattered about the house, some State work was destroyed, and paper, stationery, &c., carried off. Neither the building or the power-press were injured, and Mr. Holden expects to resume the publication of his paper in a few days.

Gov. Vance being sent for, arrived at the scene of destruction about the time the work of gutting the office had been completed.
He asked one of the officers to assemble his men as he wished to address them.
The men at once formed into line and the Governor addressed them, begging them to disperse and go to their quarters, which they promised to do.
As soon as it was known that Governor Vance was on the ground the men desisted from the work of destruction, and fell into

ranks under orders from their officers.
The Governor then addressed them in eloquent and effective terms.
He told them in substance that he regretted to see such brave men engaged in so disreputable a work — in a proceeding fraught with dishonor to themselves and disaster to the cause for which they had nobly risked their lives upon many a hard fought field; that it pained him to know that a blow had been struck at the dearest rights of the private citizen — rights purchased by the richest blood of their patriotic fathers, and in the defence of which every man among them should be ready to lay down his life; that, although he differed from the editor of the Standard, it was his duty to extend to that gentleman the fullest protection of the law until an act of treason was committed, and that, as the Chief Magistrate of North Carolina, he would defend him, as he would every other citizen of the State, at any hazard and to the fullest extent of his ability; that they might rest assured he would be the first to punish treason as he would be the last to infringe upon the liberty of the press, or any other right secured by the Constitution of his country; that the work in which they were engaged, though undertaken, perhaps, from patriotic impulses, was really an insult to the State of North Carolina, a disgrace to the Southern cause, and without a precedent, even among the people who had shown themselves the pliant tools and abject minions of the miserable despot who rules at Washington; that the simple destruction of the private property of a single individual, though a gross outrage in itself, sank into insignificance in view of the disastrous consequences which were likely to ensue to the sacred cause of liberty — to that holy cause in which the warmest sentiments of his bosom were all enlisted — in consequence of the evil passions this act of violence would engender among our already irritated people; and that in the name of law and order, and in behalf of the quiet citizens who had been alarmed by their heedless violence, he entreated them as patriots, as soldiers, and as gentlemen, to desist from further demonstrations and to return immediately to their quarters.
Some one, apparently an officer and their leader, assured him that no further violence should be perpetrated, when, having given three hearty cheers for Gov. Vance, they marched to their camp.

This ended the excitement for the night.
There were but few citizens on the streets, the Mayor only arriving at the Standard office after the work of destruction had been completed, and the bulk of the population knew nothing of it until yesterday morning.
At an early hour, however, the news spread and many citizens visited the Standard office to see the wreck.
People talked in an excited manner, and much bad blood was visible.
The work of mob violence had been commenced at the instigation, invitation, and bidding of bad men among us, and a spirit of lawlessness was abroad.
Between 7 and 8 o'clock, before many of the citizens had come on the streets, the town bell was rung, a hundred or two citizens were assembled at the market place, and another lawless and disgraceful event is added to the affair of the night previous.
The mob entered the State Journal office and in fifteen minutes the establishment is gutted, the type thrown in the street and about the building, furniture broken up, books and papers thrown around, and other damage done.
Gov. Vance addressed this crowd in front of the office, implored them to disperse, and, after cheering for His Excellency and for Mr. Holden, they did disperse, and soon all became quiet.

No attempt was made to resist the destruction of the Standard office; for no one felt disposed to interfere with a mob composed of armed soldiers, led by their own officers.
Governor Vance, Mayor Harrison, and others exerted themselves to quell the outbreak on yesterday morning; but nothing could be done until the Journal office had been gutted.

There has been no renewal of the disturbance in Raleigh.
The Progress publishes the following card from Holden, the proprietor of the Standard:

To my Readers and Friends.--On Wednesday night last, about ten o'clock, a body of soldiers belonging to Gen. Benning's Georgia brigade, with arms in their hands, and commanded by officers, attacked my office, destroyed a part of its materials, and threw the types into pie. As the result of this I shall be compelled to suspend the publication of the Standard for a few days; but I trust I will be able soon to resume publication.
No efforts or expense will be spared to serve the paper to you as heretofore.

At the earliest moment practicable I shall put the public in possession of all the facts connected with this outrage.
It is sufficient to say, at present, that a free and loyal press has been trampled down; that the State has been insulted; that the majesty of the civil law has been set at defiance; and that an outrage has been committed on my constitutional rights which has no example, in the language of Gov. Vance, who addressed the soldiers, "even in the dominions of Abraham Lincoln." I appeal to my friends to be as calm as possible, and firm and determined; and I hope it is not necessary that I should assure them that I am undismayed, and as firmly determined as ever to maintain, at all hazards, the right of free speech and a free press.

div3.head: Per flag of truce.
div3.p:
--Late Northern Papers [new arrival This (Monday) Morning,] from New York, Philadelphia and Baltimore, of the very latest dates, at the Confederate Reading Room. Also, Yankee Pictorials.
Also on file, the latest Charleston papers, giving all the news of the movements and operations there.
Papers from all parts of the South, and all of the city papers.

div4.p: On the evening of the 10th inst, in Oregon Hill M E Church, by Rev Jas E Gates, Mr. Francis J. Rater and Miss Elizabeth V Miller, the former of Henrico county, and the latter of Richmond city.
At Charlottesville, Va, on the 10th inst, by the Rev. Mr. Meade, Lieut Rodes Massie, C. S A, of Albemarle county, to Miss Bettie G Lewis, of Charlottesville.
On the 13th inst, at 5½ o'clock, after a long and painful illness, Thos Suter, aged 63 years.
The friends and acquaintances of the family are respectfully invited to attend his funeral this (Monday) afternoon, at 3 o'clock, from his late residence, on the Westham Plankroad.

On the 12th inst., of croup.
Albert Thomas, infant son of John and Sarah J Moffat, aged 2 years 1 month and 18 days.
His funeral will take place from his grandfather's residence, on 6th, between Marshall and Clay, this (Monday) afternoon, at 4 o'clock.

At Tuscawil'a, Henrico county, on Friday evening the 11th inst, aged nearly six years. Thomas Henry Taylor, son of Capt Matthew P. Taylor, of the C S Ordnance Corps, and the adopted son of Colonel and Mrs. Thomas H Ellis.
At Annefield, in Clarke county, on the 16th of August, 1863, Annie Page, only daughter of Robert H and Lucy C Renshaw, aged two years and three days.
On the 9th of September, Davis Beauregard, infant son of Martin V and Elmima Spicer, aged 1 year 9 months and 21 days.

lg.l: I miss him in the nursery,
I am glad that he is happy,
But I shall miss him so;
I almost long to join him there,
And live with him in love;
I will not think him sleeping
In the low church yard bed,
But rather that he is keeping

div3.head: For Drewry's Bluff.--
div3.p: The steamer Schultz, Capt D J Hill, having been thoroughly painted and repaired, will for the present make one trip daily to Drewry's Bluff, leaving her wharf at Rocketts at 3 o'clock P M.
Fare for the round trip only two Dollars.
All persons are required to have passports before coming on board.

div3.head: Special notice.
div3.p: --Our sale of Groceries, Manufactured Tobacco, Bar Iron, Nails, and Blockade Goods, is postponed from Tuesday to Friday next, the 18th inst., as a portion of the goods we shall offer (a notice of which will hereafter be given) will not arrive in time to offer before Friday next.

div3.head: Special notice.
div3.p: --I would respectfully call the attention of buyers to the handsome Furniture, Brussels Carpets, &c., at my sale this morning at 10 o'clock, at the residence of G W. Harris, Esq., Venable, between 21st and 22d sts, Union Hill.
Our regular sale of Groceries will take place next Wednesday, at which time we will offer

div3.head: Movements of the enemy in the West.
div3.p:
--Rosecrans is moving about from place to place, but making no decided forward movement.
Skirmishers are thrown out by the enemy at various places from Ringgold to Alpine.
From fifteen to twenty thousand of the enemy are said to be forty miles from Rome, Georgia, their prisoners say, waiting for their wagon train.--A general engagement is not expected soon unless Gen. Bragg attacks.

div4.head: [second Dispatch.]
div4.p:
--On Friday, the 21st of August, a portion of Rosecrans's cavalry fired across the Tennessee river into Chattanooga.
For a few days feints were made at Harrison, 20 miles above Chattanooga, and below, at Bridgeport.
By the 26th the enemy had crossed at Bridgeport, the small force then at that point falling back, and Chattanooga having been evacuated by the citizens.
The enemy's movements were slow and cautious; and at length they passed down Will's Valley, through Dade county, Ga., in considerable force to flank Bragg's army on the left, by way of Rome, and the cavalry reached Alpine, in Chattanooga county, Ga., on the Alabama line, twenty-eight miles northwest of Rome.
On the 9th of September they had a skirmish with Col. Avery, commanding the 3d and 4th Georgia cavalry, who fell back after a hard fight.
The movement was anticipated.
In the meantime, most of Burnside's forces are understood to have joined Rosecrans, and pressed in considerable force on towards Bragg through the gaps of the mountains in Walker and Chattanooga counties, Ga. Small parties of the enemy's cavalry have visited Tunnell Hill, Catoosa, and Dalton, on the State road.
It is reported that Gen. Forrest was wounded in a skirmish near Dalton yesterday.
It is believed the main body of Rosecrans's army has fallen back to Chattanooga.--He has refused, and it is believed will still refuse, to give Bragg battle, but will aim at wintering in Chattanooga.

div3.head: From Mississippi.
div3.p:
--All quiet in front.
No news of any kind has been received within the last forty-eight hours. The cavalry under Gen. Lee were reviewed yesterday by Gen. Hardee.

div3.head: From Charleston.
div3.p:
--There was considerable firing last night chiefly from our batteries.
All quiet this morning.

div3.head: Metropolitan Hall.
div3.p: This (Monday) night, Sept. 14, 1863,
Sixth night of the
New Iron-Clad Opera Troupe.

House crowded to is utmost capacity to see the performance of this
Excelsior Troupe.
Go early to secure seats.
To-night the side splitting Farce,
the black Statue.

Grand Free Exhibition of
Dissolving Views,
from all parts of the globe in front of the Hall.
Incomprehensible, Inexhaustible Budget to-night.
See programmes.

div3.head:
Fashionable
Dancing Academy;

p.hi: By Prof J St Maur Bingham.

div3.p: Exchange Hotel, cor 14th and Franklin sts. Entrance on 14th st.--Ladies' private entrance.
Prof Bingham presents his compliments to the Ladies and Gentlemen of Richmond, and respectfully announces to them that he will resume the duties of his profession.
Tuesday evening, Sept. 15th, 1863, 4 o'clock, for children.
Wednesday, 4 P. M., for ladies.
Wednesday, 8 P. M., for gentlemen.
Children's classes: Tuesdays and Thursdays 4 P. M., Saturdays 11 A. M.
Ladies' classes: Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays 4 P. M.
Gentlemen's classes: Mondays, Wednesdays and Saturdays 8 P. M.
Terms ascertained on application.
An early attendance is requested.
Practicing parties every Thursday evening at 8 ½ o'clock.
Private classes at schools or at residences will be formed if requested.

div3.head: Night School.
div3.p:
--The subscriber will open a Night School at a central location on Shockoe Hill on the 1st of October, and will pay special attention to teaching Mathematics and preparing pupils for the Virginia Military Institute.
Apply at Mrs. M G Pendleton's, on 4th street, between Main and Franklin.

div3.head: School for young ladies,
div3.p: Corner of Grace and Foushee sts.

The duties of our School will be resumed on the 1st of October.
For particulars apply at the institution.

div3.head: Misses Clopton's School for young ladies, on Franklin street, between 3d and 4th.
div3.p:
--The duties of this School will be resumed on the 1st day of October, 1863.
Particulars made known on application.

div3.head: Private School.
div3.p: --On the first Monday in October, the Misses Lizzie and Sallie Grattan will open a school for a limited number of young ladies, at their residence on 7th street, between Franklin and Grace.

G. L. C. Salter's school for boys will open on Monday, the 1st inst, (September,) on 4th st, between Clay and Marshall. Terms (moderate as the trying exigencies of the times allow) will be made known on application to the subscriber, or by circular.

div3.head:
Miss Lucy King's
School for young ladies.
div3.p: The next session of this school will commence on the 1st of October, 1863.
For further information apply to Miss L King, second door from the corner of Broad and Mayo sts.

div3.head: Mrs. M C Gary
div3.p:
will resume the duties of her school on the 1st of October.
Residence on 4th street, Gamble's Hill.

div3.head:
Southern Female Institute,
Richmond, Va.
div3.p:
The duties of this Institution will be resumed on the 1st Monday in October, and close on the 1st of July, 1864.
For terms apply to

div3.head: For sale
div3.p: --A very fine, handsome Gold Watch and heavy Gold Chain; can be seen at Messrs Archer & Daly's office, 223 Main st, corner of 9th, Richmond, Va

div3.head: Boarding.
div3.p:
--Three or four gentlemen can be accommodated with Board and Lodging in a private family, on 4th street, between Cary and Canal, if early application is made.
Also, a few day boarders will be accommodated.

div3.head: School Furniture for sale
div3.p: --Consisting of Desks, Benches, Chairs, &c. Apply to W L Miller, at the store of Harvey, Hunt, James & Co.

div3.head: Millinery
div3.p: --At Madams son's. My store will be closed on Monday and Tuesday, and reopened on Wednesday with a new stock of goods, at 56 Main st.

div3.head: By A. D. Williams, Auctioneer.
div3.p:
A good Farm, nine miles North of Richmond, for sale at auction — By request of Mr. John D Thomas, I will sell at auction, on Monday, 21st Sept., at 11 o'clock A M, upon the premises, his farm, known as "Mosby's," situated on the Mountain Road, and within one mile of the R and F R R. It contains 230 acres, of which about 100 are cleared and his highly productive; the remainder is in original growth of wood and timber.
On this place there is a comfortable dwelling, with seven rooms, situated in a beautiful grove; a large brick barn, and other buildings.
There is also an excellent orchard of choice fruits.

This is justly regarded as one of the most valuable farms of its size in the county.
Persons wishing to purchase are invited to examine it before the day of sale.
Terms--To suit purchasers.
div3.closer:
A D Williams, Auct'r.
P S — At the same time will be sold a Negro Man, who is said to be a very superior Gardener.
A D W, Auct'r. se 14

div3.head: Beautiful Cottage residence on Grove street, in Sidney, at auction.
div3.p:
--On Friday; 18th September, at 5½ o'clock P M, will be sold upon the premises, the Italian Cottage, recently occupied by Major J F Wren, situated on Grove st, just opposite the former residence of Mr. Jno E Johnson.
It has about seven rooms besides a kitchen and about an acre of land attached.

The situation is in the most desirable portion of the suburbs, and the arrangement of the premises displays considerable taste.
The house being now vacant, immediate possession will be given.
Terms as purchasers may wish.

div3.head: Valuable real Estate, on the Southwest Corner of Broad and 3d sts. At auction.
div3.p:
--On Thursday, 17th September, at 5 o'clock P M. upon the premises, will be sold the above situated property, occupied by Mr. F Laube.
It fronts 36 feet and runs back.--feet.
The attention of capitalists is invited to the sale of this truly valuable property.
Terms--A portion in cash; and the balance on a reasonable credit; or the whole in cash, as the purchaser may prefer.

div3.head: Trustee's sale of House and Lot on Oregon Hill.
div3.p: --As trustee in a deed of trust from G Hermann and wife to the subscriber, dated--May, 1856, duly recorded in Richmond Hustings Court on the 20th May, 1856, I shall in execution of the said deed, (the said Hermann being a non-resident of this States,) at the request of the majority of creditors therein named, proceed to sell, at public auction, for cash, on the premises, on Thursday, the 24th day of September, 1863, at 4 o'clock P. M. (if fair, if not, the first fair flay therafter.) the House and Lot, designated as letter "C" In Howard's plan, fronting 30 feet, running back 108 feet, and formerly occupied by the said G Hermann and family and now occupied by his daughter.

div3.head: Public sale.
div3.p: --Will be sold at public auction, in the county of Hanover, 2½ miles from Ashland, on the premises of the subscriber, on Wednesday, the 23d day of the present month, (if fair, if not, the next fair day,) all the crops of corn, wheat, rye, oats, fodder, hay, straw, &c, 37 head of fat sheep, 20 head of hogs, milch cows, wheat machine, wheat fan, all in complete order, plantation utensils, household and kitchen furniture, &c, &c.
div3.closer: Terms — Cash. Slaughter B Bullock. se 14--M14&M21 2t

div3.head: By E. S. Pleasants, Auct'r.
div3.p: Handsome Pianos, Furniture, &c, for sale at auction.--I will sell at 10 o'clock on Tuesday, the 15th inst, at my store--
2 handsome pianos, in mahogany cases
1 handsome set parlor furniture, comprising
Tete-a-tete, 6 spring-seat chairs and rocking chair
Walnut extension table, bedsteads
Carpets, rugs, crockery and glassware
Several excellent cooking stoves
Besides a general assortment of other articles of
Household and kitchen furniture.
I will sell the pianos at 11 o'clock, one of which is 6 octave, in complete order, and has a very handsome cover.

div3.head: By Sumner & Arents, Auctioneers,
div3.p: Auction Sale of Dry Goods, Boots and Shoes, Fancy Goods, &c.--We will sell, on Wednesday next, the 16th inst, at our warehouse, commencing at 9½ o'clock, a general assortment of Dry Goods.

Boots and Shoes,
Hats,
Fancy Goods,
Notions, &c.
Particulars will appear on Tuesday.

div3.head: By Dunlop, Moncure & Co, Auct's.
div3.p: Dry Goods, Stationery, &c, for sale at Auction.--On Tuesday, the 22d inst, commencing at 9 o'clock, we will sell by catalogue, at our auction store, a large and valuable assortment of English Dry Goods, Stationery, &c, consisting in part of

list.item: 51 pieces extra super white and drab satteens
1878 lbs blue and white and black thread
16 cases (640 reams) letter and cap paper; assorted as to quality and ruling

div3.p: all the above goods were purchased of the manufacturers or their agents, in English markets, by a merchant of this city familiar with the wants of the trade, and for quality and style of nuish is equal, if not superior, to any lot of goods ever offered for sale in this market.

list.head: also,
list.item: 14 bates 4-4 sheetings and 7-8 shortings and burss

div3.p: with other goods suited to the trade.
Catalogues and goods ready for examination on Monday, 21st inst.
Sale without reserve for cash.
div3.closer:
Dunlop, Moncure & Co,
Auctioneers. se 12--tds

div4.p: Buggies, spring Wagons, Smiths' Tools, &c, at auction.--we will sell on Friday, September 11th, at the shop of R O Sterling, on 17th, near Marshall street, commencing at 10 o'clock a M., the following and other articles:

div4.head: N B
div4.p: --As Mr. Sterling contemplates a change of business, all persons owning articles at his shop are hereby notified to come forward before the day of sate, pay charges, and take them away.
The above sale is postponed to Tuesday, the 15th inst.

div3.head: Furniture, Piano, Sewing Machines, &c, at auction.
div3.p: --On Wednesday, the 16th inst, commencing at 10 o'clock A M, we will sell at our salesrooms, No. 192 Main street, a varied assortment of Goods, consisting in part of the following articles.

list.item: 1 very superior mahogany piano, 6 octaves, of Stoddard & Dunham's make.
1 excellent walnut cabinet sewing machine, of Wheeler & Wilson's make
Windsor, cane seat, and parlor chairs
150 yds cotton, linen, and damask goods, a little damaged
A small invoice call skin boots

div3.head: By Chas. T. Wortham & Co., Auct'rs.
div3.p: Damaged Sugars for Sale — On Tuesday, the 15th day of Sept., 1863, at 11 o'clock A M, at the Tobacco Factory of Plea ants & Frayser, on 20th street, between Main and Franklin, in the city of Richmond, I shall sell, at public auction, on account of whom it may concern, fifteen hogsheads of Sugar, damaged by water in transit from Petersburg to Richmond, via the river.
div3.closer:
Lewis H Frayser.
Chas T Wortham & Co, Auct'r. se 11--4t

div3.head: For sale
div3.p:
--A good and reliable Family Horse, perfectly sound, and works well to any sort of vehicle; also rides well.
Apply to
div3.closer:
P H Starke, Agricultural store,
3 doors above St Charles Hotel. se 14--6t

div3.head: For sale
div3.p:
--A No. 1 bay Mare, with saddle and bridle.
She is an excellent riding animal, and will suit for cavalry service.
For particulars apply at Duke's stables, on 18th street, or at my store, on Main street, between 17th and 18th.

div3.head: For sale
div3.p:
--A Morgan Stallion, 6 years old; works and rides well.
He can be seen at
div3.closer:
Mr. J C Cocke's, 2d st,
Between Clay and Leigh. se 10--31

div3.head: Substitute.
div3.p: --$6,000 will be paid for a Substitute who is over 45 years old. Apply at Chimborazo Hospital, 1st division, ward of Richmond, Va.

div4.p:
Will be offered for sale at public auction, on Monday, the 14th September, at 12 o'clock, the Farm now owned and occupied by Mr. John Walker, situated seven miles north of Richmond and three-quarters of a mile from Hungary station on the Richmond, Fredericksburg and Potomac Railroad, and near the Brook Turnpike.
It contains 245 acres, nearly 200 acres of which are in woods, the larger portion of it heavily set in wood and timber of good quality.
The balance is in a good state of improvement and cultivation.
There is a good two story dwelling with brick basement, containing four rooms, with other necessary buildings.
The very large quantity of wood and timber on this land, and its being only about a half-mile from Hungary station, over a level road, readers this a very valuable piece of property at this time.

div4.head: Also,
div4.p:
On the same day, at 2 o'clock, will be offered the small Farm at present occupied by the subscribes, containing 62 acres; 40 acres of it open land, is a good state of cultivation, the balance in wood.
This is very excellent gardening land.
It is 6 ½ miles north of Richmond by the Brook road, and 1 ½ miles from Hungary station.
A good two-story dwelling, with passages, portices, &c, and other out buildings, a lot of fine young fruit trees, a spring of the very best water within seventy-five yards of the house, and a stream of water running pearly through the centre of the place, upon which there are about 10 acres of fine meadow land.
Mr. Walker, who resides on the first-named place, will show either place to persons wishing to purchase.
div4.closer: Terms — At sale. P H Waldrop. se 12--2t

div3.head: By James M. Taylor, Auctioneer.
div3.p:
Carpenter's Shop, corner of Cary and 4th sts, at auction.--At the request of Mr. David Gibson, I will sell, on Monday, the 14th September, at 11 o'clock M, the large framed Carpenter's Shop located as above, and but recently built.
I will also sell the finished work for a two story dwelling and inches, together with all the tools, work benches, and apparatus usually found in a house joiner's establishment.
div3.closer: Terms.--Cash. Jas M Taylor, Auct. se 11

div3.p:
Brick Tenements, on the North side Drival st, near the late residence of J B Prentiss, at auction.--I will sell on the premises, on Monday, 14th September, at 4 ½ o'clock, the two brick tenements located as above.
Each tenement has 5 rooms, with a kitchen.
The lot fronts 20 feet and runs back 157 feet to an alley.
Terms made known on day of sale.

div3.head: By Pulliam, Hanes & Weisiger, Aucts.
div3.p:
Land for sale at Auction.--We will sell at auction, at Chesterfield C H, at 12 o'clock, on the 14th of September, (Court day,) a tract of land, containing about 400 acres, and located about one mile of Clover Hill R R, 8 miles of Chesterfield C H, 13 miles of Petersburg, and adjoining the lands of Richmond and Petersburg R R Co, Mr. Middleton, Dr. Robinson, and others.
Forty acres cleared, and four hundred acres in wood and timber, one or two small dwelling houses, out of repair, upon it. The attention of persons who wish to invest in property that will always bring them a good income by a little attention is called to this sale.
Terms--One third cash, and balance in one, two and three years; or cash as the purchaser may desire.

div3.head: By Owens & Willis, Auctioneers,
div3.p: Household and Kitchen Furniture, Horse and Buggy, Shoemakers' Took, Leather, &c, at auction.--Will be sold at auction, on Monday next at 10 o'clock, at the store formerly occupied by a Hardingham, Broad street, between 2d and 3d, a lot of

list.item: a large lot of bed clothing, &c.

div3.p: also, about
and at 11 o'clock,
div3.closer:
By order of W. Pfeiffer.
Sale conducted by Owens & Willis, Auct'rs. se 12

div3.head: By E. S. Pleasants, Auct.
div3.p: Genteel. Household Furniture at Auction.--On Monday, the 14th instant, I will sell at the residence of G W Harris, Esq, on Venable, between 21st and 22d streets, (Union Hill,) all his Household and Kitchen Furniture, embracing.

list.item: 1 entirely new Brussells carpet, very large

list.head: also,
list.item: A general assortment of kitchen furniture.

div3.p: At the same time the House can be rented privately.
div3.closer:
E S Pleasants,
Auctioneer se 10

div3.head: By Williamson & Co., Auct's, 192 Main st.
div3.p: Household and Kitchen Furniture at auction.--On Monday, 14th inst, commencing at 10 o'clock A M., we will sell at the residence of Mr. Chas Lobbert, on Marshall st, between 5th and 6th, a very desirable assortment of household and kitchen furniture consisting of the following and other articles,

div3.head: Free negroes at Auction.
div3.p:
--By virtue of an order of the Hustings Court of the city of Richmond I will sell on Monday next, the 14th inst, (that being Court day,) in front of the City Hall, at 10 o'clock A M, Patrick Coleman and Job Green, free negroes, convicted by said Court of grand larceny and ordered to be sold into absolute slavery.
Also, an old man named John, committed to jail for going at large and ordered to be sold.
div3.closer:
Thomas U Dudley,
Serg't City of Richmond se 10--4t

div3.head: By James M. Taylor, Auctioneer.
div3.p:
For Rent at auction.--I will rent at auction, on Wednesday, the 16th Sept., at 4 o'clock, on the premises, on Brook Avenue, between Clay and Leigh streets, for 12 months, a very neat and comfortable Brick Dwelling, with 7 rooms.
Immediate possession given.

Seventy-five Acres of Land in Henrico county on the York River Railroad, and the road leading to Blackey's Mill, 1 ¼ miles from the city — At the request of Mr. Thos L Pleasants, who resides upon the place, I will offer for sale, upon the premises, on Tuesday, the 15th September, at 4 ½ o'clock, the above valuable piece of land, in five lots, from 6 to 25 acres each.
On one of the lots, which contains about 20 acres, is a new framed dwelling, containing six large and three small rooms, and all necessary out houses.
A plat of the land can be seen at my office.
Terms cash.

div3.head: Store and dwelling on the South side of Broad near first st, at auction.
div3.p:
--I will sell on Wednesday, 16th September, at 4 ½ o'clock, the granite front store and dwelling located as above, now occupied by Mr. Jas Gnell as a grocery.
The dwelling has 6 rooms.
There is also upon the premises a brick building with 4 rooms and smoke house.
The nts on Broad at 24 feet by 150 feet deep to an alley.
This property is an excellent stand for business.
Terms made known on day of sale

div3.head: Valuable House and Lot on Grace and 5th sts at auction.
div3.p:
--I will sell upon the premises, on Thursday, 17th September, at 5 o'clock P M, that valuable private residence located as above, and at present occupied by Mr. A A Huglas.
This property is so well known that it is deemed unnecessary to give a minute description of it.
Terms made known on day of sale.

div3.head: By Robinson, Adams & Co., Aucts.
div3.p:
Sale of Groceries, Nand Tobacco.
Iron, Nails, and Blockade Goods, at auction,--At 10 o'clock, on Friday, the 18th inst, we will offer--

list.head: Also,
list.item: 60 bars square, flat and round Wrought Iron

list.head: also,
list.item: Lot in bags and papers Tobacco

div3.p: Parties desiring to offer goods at the above sale will please send invoices and samples early Monday morning.
div3.closer:
Rolinson, Adams & Co,
Auctioneers se 11

div3.head: By Thomas W. Keence, Auctioneer,
div3.p: Administrator's sale of Household Furniture at auction.--Will be sold on Tuesday morning, September 15th, commencing at 10 o'clock, at the residence of Mr. E Sydnor, on 1st street, between Cary and Canal, a lot of Household Furniture, consisting in part of
div3.closer: Thos W Keeser, Auct'r se 12

div3.head: For hire
div3.p:
--A servant woman, who is a good nurse and house servant.
To a good home the servant will be moderate.
Apply at the 3d door above st, on Cary.
